tossups.question: This figure’s Etruscan counterparts, often depicted with Vanth, swing hammers at Laris Pulenas’s head in a sarcophagus relief. Deadly vapors spill from this figure’s sacred cave of Aornum (“ah-OR-num”). Seneca relates how Hercules overpowered this figure with his own pole. In The Frogs, the slave Xanthias is forced to run around a lake by this figure, who discusses frog-swan songs with Dionysus. During his (*) katabasis, Aeneas pacified this child of Erebus and Nyx with a golden bough. An obol (“OH-bull”) placed in the mouth, rather than over the eyes, is given to this psychopomp of the Acheron (“AK-er-on”), who forces the unburied to wait 100 years before receiving transport. For 10 points, name this ferryman of the Styx who guides souls to Hades.
tossups.answer: Charon [or Kharon or Charos; accept Charun or Karu or Karun; accept Charonium; reject “Chiron” (“KAI-run”)] (Welcome to the underworld that is the PACE NSC.)
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~27141~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: The value “violet” is added to this theory in the Pati–Salam model. This theory cannot include the decay products of any R-parity-conserving theory’s LSP, which is a WIMP in the “minimal supersymmetric” version of this theory. Unobserved heavy neutrinos are implied by extending this theory with the type I (“one”) seesaw mechanism. This theory’s gauge interactions are explained by (*) grand unified theories. This theory’s failure to explain gravitation could be resolved by the discovery of the graviton. Columns represent three “generations” of this theory in its representation as a four-by-four grid next to the Higgs boson. Three of the fundamental forces are explained by, for 10 points, what theory underlying particle physics?
tossups.answer: Standard Model [prompt on grand unified theories or GUTs until “grand unified theories” is read by asking “on what theory is that theory based?”] (“LSP” stands for “lightest supersymmetric particle.”)
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Science - Physics> ~28179~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: Specific term required. One of these people died while leading an ill-fated expedition whose few survivors included the enslaved man Estevanico. One of these people known as “the Madman” styled himself the “Wrath of God, Prince of Freedom.” Several of these people funded monuments in their hometowns across Extremadura. One of these people wrote a “true history” that recounts how another of them wept during a 1520 event which translates to “The (*) Sad Night.” A woman who translated for one of these people was known as “La Malinche.” After winning the Battle of Cajamarca (“kah-huh-MAR-kuh”), one of these people ordered Atahualpa’s (“ah-tah-HWAL-pa’s”) execution. For 10 points, give the Spanish or Portuguese term for soldier-explorers like Hernán Cortés, who conquered much of the Americas.
tossups.answer: conquistadors [or conquistadores; prompt on Spanish or Portuguese people or Spaniards until read; prompt on sailors; prompt on conquerors or soldiers or explorers before mentioned] (The first clue refers to the Narváez Expedition. Lope de Aguirre was known as “the Madman.” The fourth sentence is about La Noche Triste, recounted by Bernal Diaz.)
tossups.metadata: Jon Suh, History - European - 1500-1900

tossups.question: Richard Katz believed that this psychologist failed to cite time studying the Giving Ceremony of the Blackfoot. This psychologist imagined a culturally healthy utopia called Eupsychia (“yew-sike-ee-uh”) in a “Theory Z” outlining the ideal organization of companies. A cognitive bias of repeatedly using the same tool for different problems is called this psychologist’s “Hammer.” A group of people studied by this psychologist have Being-values that define their (*) metamotivations and may have “peak experiences.” This psychologist’s paper “A Theory of Human Motivation” developed a model often visualized as a pyramid with self-actualization at its top. For 10 points, name this psychologist who formulated a namesake “hierarchy of needs.”
tossups.answer: Abraham Maslow [accept Maslow’s hierarchy of needs or Maslow’s Hammer]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Social Science - Psychology> ~28209~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: In a story, a man proposes hunting these animals after musing on a girl’s name that mixes “memory and desire.” A story titled for these animals opens by describing a woman reading an article titled “Sex Is Fun –– or Hell” while waiting for men to finish using hotel phones. The protagonist of a story recounts the “tragic life” of these animals, who gorge themselves in their (*) feeding holes until they become too large to escape. In a story titled for these animals, a young girl named Sybil Carpenter converses on the beach and has her feet kissed by Seymour Glass, who later commits suicide. For 10 points, J. D. Salinger wrote a story about “A Perfect Day for” what fictional fruit-eating animals?
tossups.answer: bananafish [accept “A Perfect Day for Bananafish”; accept bananafishes; prompt on fish]
tossups.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~27223~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: The Jominy (“JAH-min-ee”) end-quench test measures how much this property can be increased. This property is locally increased by precipitating nitrides at a metal’s surface. The strain-induced increase in this property is balanced by a loss of cross-sectional area when a material first necks. A martensitic transformation boosts this property by hundreds of Brinell. Work increases this property by rearranging a metal’s dislocations. (*) Annealing decreases this property and increases ductility. Alloying iron to steel doubles this property, as estimated by the yield stress in an indentation test. Scratch tests compare this property to minerals like quartz and talc. For 10 points, name this property measured on the Mohs scale.
tossups.answer: hardness [or hardenability; accept hard; accept yield stress or tensile strength or tensile stress until “yield stress” is read; prompt on strength or toughness; prompt on Young’s modulus or shear modulus or bulk modulus or modulus or stiffness]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27614~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: In 2021, this city gave Jane Gilbert the first-in-the-nation title of Chief Heat Officer. Phrases such as “get down from the car” exemplify a newly-emerging English dialect named for this city. Each October, this American city’s Art Week is anchored by Art Basel (“BAH-zul”). Officials in this city rejected a 20-foot-high seawall that would have run past its Brickell financial district and was proposed after (*) Hurricane Irma. A billboard asking Silicon Valley tech bros to “DM me” was erected by this city’s Republican mayor, Francis Suarez. In 2021, 98 people were killed when a condo collapsed in this city’s suburb of Surfside. For 10 points, name this city located in a county partly named for Francis L. Dade in South Florida.
tossups.answer: Miami [accept Miami-Dade; accept Miami Beach]

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read answerline carefully. Note to players: Description acceptable. Like the acolyte, this action’s performer was dubbed a ministry instead of a minor order by the apostolic letter Ministeria Quaedam (“KWAY-dohm”) after Vatican II. Years A, B, and C refer to Matthew, Mark, and Luke during this action’s three-year cycle. The Responsorial Psalm is sung between two instances of this action. During the Catholic Liturgy of the Word, a congregant performs this action after bowing before the altar and approaching the ambo, a type of elevated (*) pulpit. An Evangeliary is used for this action. It’s not the end of mass, but Catholics reply “Thanks be to God” after two instances of these actions, three of which precede the homily. For 10 points, name this action performed during mass by lectors and a priest using the Book of the Gospels.
tossups.answer: reading the Bible aloud [accept reading Biblical scripture; accept reading passages from the Old Testament or New Testament or the Gospels or the Epistles or the Apocrypha or the deuterocanonical books or specific biblical books; accept reading passages from the Evangeliary or Lectionary; accept selecting passages from the Evangeliary or Lectionary; accept answers about reading the Word of God; prompt on speaking or talking; reject “giving a sermon” or “preaching”]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Christian Practice> ~28039~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: This modern-day country contains a fractally designed wall that may be the world’s largest man-made earthwork structure. In this country, an archaeologist observed a farmer using a Nok terracotta head as a scarecrow. The influence of the Ọọ̀ni of Ilé-Ifẹ̀ (“OH-knee of ee-lay ee-FEH”) in this country was eclipsed by the Oyo Empire. In this country, the city-states of Zazzau and Gobir were conquered by (*) Usman dan Fodio during the 19th-century Fulani jihads. This country’s [emphasize] western neighbor shares its name with a set of bronzes that Henry Rawson pillaged from a kingdom in this country. Obas ruled this country’s south while Hausa kings controlled its north. For 10 points, name this modern-day country home to the Igbo and Yoruba people.
tossups.answer: Nigeria [or Federal Republic of Nigeria; reject “Benin” or “Benin Bronzes”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - World - African> ~25942~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: This character orders a man to “eclipse himself” by the time he claps three times. The real-life inspiration for this character wrote about meeting a race with a musical language on the Moon in his novel The Other World. That man’s supposed death from a falling beam was fictionalized as this character’s death after visiting a convent. During a duel, this character delivers a ballad that repeats “thrust home!” This title character of an 1897 play often mentions his (*) panache (“pa-NASH”). This man offers to write a love letter for the poet Christian (“crees-tee-AHN”), but falls for the addressee of that letter, Roxane. For 10 points, an Edmond Rostand play chronicles what French author and swordfighter with a large nose?
tossups.answer: Cyrano de Bergerac (“SEE-rah-no de BUR-zhe-rack”) [or Savinien de Cyrano de Bergerac]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - European - Drama> ~25246~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: This architect’s book Autobiography of an Idea ends with a description of a series of concentric arches called the Golden Door. A tripartite building now named for this architect was the first to feature large windows flanked by double hung windows and a rounded, cast-iron entrance. This architect frequently used Syrian arches and entwined Celtic patterns, the latter of which appears interlaced with bull’s eye windows on a brewery office building. Buffalo’s (*) Guaranty Building uses terracotta to replace the brick that Dankmar Adler and this architect used for a steel-framed skyscraper. Frank Lloyd Wright was an apprentice under, for 10 points, what architect of the Wainwright Building who used the mantra “form follows function?”
tossups.answer: Louis Sullivan [or Louis Henry Sullivan; accept Sullivan Center]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Architecture> ~28600~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: The acronym “ESKAPE” (“escape”) lists species that exhibit this trait by expressing genes like mcr1 or a metallo·enzyme named for New Delhi. BioBricks vectors are labelled A, C, K, or T based on the type of this trait they encode. In a 2016 time-lapse video, Michael Baym tracked the emergence of this trait caused by mutations to dnaQ (“D N A Q”) across a meter-wide agar plate. This trait, encoded by genes like bla (“blah”) or tetM (“tet M”), is (*) spread between populations by horizontal gene transfer. This trait can be encoded by enzymes that degrade beta-lactams or pump out fluoro·quino·lones. Hospital-acquired infections are often caused by bacteria with this trait like MRSA (“MURR-suh”). For 10 points, name this trait of “superbugs” that are immune to some drugs.
tossups.answer: antibiotic resistance [or resistance to antibiotics; or immunity to antibiotics; or antimicrobial resistance or AMR; or antibacterial resistance; accept beta-lactam resistance or ampicillin resistance or kanamycin resistance or vancomycin resistance or methicillin resistance or methoprim resistance; accept drug resistance until “drugs” is read and prompt on it afterwards; accept superbugs until it is read; prompt on resistance or immunity by asking, “To what?”; reject “antibiotic” or “antimicrobial” or “antibacterial” by itself]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27068~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: For 211 years, the only version of this play performed was a David Garrick adaptation with a balcony for a Pedant. This play’s events are imagined as “the best dream that ever I had in my life” by a drunkard who is dressed in noble clothes. A discussion of falconry appears in this play in the same act that a woman explains she was “bedazzled with the sun” when she mistook (*) Vincentio for a maid. “Fie fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow” opens this play’s last speech, which is responded to with the phrase “Come on and kiss me.” A man who desires to “wive it wealthily in Padua” in this play is the abusive Petruchio. For 10 points, Katherina is controversially made “more obedient” to her husband in what play by William Shakespeare?
tossups.answer: The Taming of the Shrew
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - British - Drama> ~27701~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Composer and type of piece required. The composer of these orchestral pieces cheekily suggested seven “recipes” for writing them, such as avoiding it altogether or plagiarizing yourself, like when he twice copied from Aureliano in Palmira. One of these pieces from 1816 features the eighth note phrase [read slowly] “three pick up Bs, then C, B” and its composer’s namesake “crescendo.” After a storm is depicted in one of these pieces, the English horn and flute play a (*) ranz des vaches (“rahn deh VAHSH”). The most frequently excerpted section from The Thieving Magpie is one of these works, as is one that ends with a lively “March of the Swiss Soldiers” often used to depict galloping horses. For 10 points, name these orchestral pieces that open William Tell and The Barber of Seville.
tossups.answer: overtures by Gioachino Rossini [prompt on Rossini operas by asking “what purely orchestral works from them?”; prompt on overtures by asking “by which composer?”; prompt on William Tell Overture or Guillaume Tell Overture or overture to The Barber of Seville or overture to Il barbiere di Siviglia by asking “by which composer?”]
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Classical> ~27935~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: Austria’s “Dapper” Joe Farren ran chorus lines in this city during an era where the rich patronized the Art Deco Paramount nightclub on Bubbling Well Road. This city was where the “January Storm” that purged the Four Olds took place and names a 1972 Communique where the Nixon administration “acknowledged” claims on Taiwan. The (*) Pǔdōng New Area in this city benefited from the creation of a Special Economic Zone in 1993 and lies across the river from The Bund. The opening of the Yángshān Port in 2005 helped this city become the busiest container port in the world. It’s not Shēnzhèn, but in 1990, Dèng Xiǎopíng re-opened a stock exchange in this city. For 10 points, name this financial capital of China.
tossups.answer: Shànghǎi
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~27282~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: These objects name natural transformations from a constant diagram to a diagram of the same shape, “universal” examples of which are category theoretic limits. Vector space subsets that are closed under positive scalar multiplication are named for these objects. In the standard parameterization of these objects, replacing the equation “z equals r” with “z equals theta” instead yields a helicoid. “Excesses” and “defects” are derived from these objects in the best-known work by (*) Apollonius of Perga. Slicing a “double” one of these objects with a plane yields hyperbolas and parabolas as namesake “sections.” For 10 points, name these surfaces that contain a volume of one-third pi r-squared h.
tossups.answer: cones [accept cone of a functor or cones of a functor or universal cones or Conics or conic sections or double cones; prompt on nappe by asking, “What is the name of a single nappe?”] (The words “hyperbola” and “ellipse” come from the Ancient Greek words for “excess” and “defect,” respectively.)
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~27127~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: This author completed an English translation of the spiritualist Kabir that celebrates how “God is within us.” The speaker of a poem by this author does not know “how to answer” questions about the meaning of songs as “you sit there smiling.” The conclusion of a collection by this author asks for all his songs to gather “into a single current” and “flow to a sea of silence.” The speaker of a poem by this author searches for a place (*) “where knowledge is free” and “where the mind is without fear.” A “ruler of the minds of all people” is praised in an anthem by this author, who opened a 1910 poetry collection with the declaration “Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure.” For 10 points, name this Bengali poet of Gitanjali.
tossups.answer: Rabindranath Tagore (The anthem is “Jana Gana Mana.”)
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28507~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: The “Great Pumpkin” objection attacks a position named for this field that was co-developed by William Alston. Linda Zagzebski developed a neo-Aristotelian view in this field inspired by Ernest Sosa’s The Raft and the Pyramid. Alvin Plantinga’s “reformed” variant of this field holds certain claims to be “properly basic.” Susan Haack synthesized two major positions in this field as “foundherentism.” A paper in this field describes a (*) “case” in which Smith and Jones apply for the same job, and Jones has ten coins in his pocket. Edmund Gettier critiqued the Meno and Theaetetus’s definition of this field’s central concept as “justified true belief.” For 10 points, what field of philosophy is the study of knowledge?
tossups.answer: epistemology [accept reformed epistemology; accept virtue epistemology; prompt on philosophy of knowledge until “knowledge” is read; prompt on belief or epistemic justification; prompt on philosophy until read]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~28100~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: A man with this surname names a town where Stonewall Jackson’s forces killed Colonel Dixon S. Miles before capturing a Union garrison in September 1862. Brothers with this surname founded a publication that originally published The “Brains” and other cartoons by Thomas Nast. George Washington’s grandnephew Lewis was taken hostage in a town named for this surname in an incident resolved by troops under (*) Robert E. Lee. That town named for a person with this surname housed the second-ever US Armory, a facility captured in 1859 in a failed attempt to spark a slave revolt. For 10 points, give this surname in the name of a West Virginia town targeted by abolitionist John Brown.
tossups.answer: Harper [accept Harpers Ferry; accept Harper’s Weekly]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - Pre-1865> ~25386~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A 2016 exhibition of this artist’s “Visions of Genius” at the Noordbrabants Museum authenticated a depiction of St. Anthony separated from a funnel by a river. The burning of this artist’s hometown may have inspired several blackened buildings in the background of his paintings. This artist depicted a man dropping coins into a chest as a skeleton pokes through a door and points a silver arrow at a man in bed. Joan Miró’s The Tilled Field was inspired by a painting by this artist in which (*) birds appear gifting strawberries. This artist may have depicted himself as a pale white “tree man” who appears below a knife squished by two ears in a chaotic “Hell scene.” For 10 points, name this Dutch artist of The Garden of Earthly Delights.
tossups.answer: Hieronymus Bosch [or Jheronimus Bosch or Jheronimus van Aken]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - Misc> ~28485~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: In this city, Demetrio Vallejo was accused of plotting with a Soviet embassy during a 1959 rail strike. In 2006, this city was occupied for 47 days by protestors demanding that the TEPJF issue a recount. A paramilitary group called The Falcons lend their name to a massacre in this city that took place during a Corpus Christi festival in 1971. President (*) Miguel de la Madrid was heckled after an earthquake devastated this city in 1986. Over 300 student protestors were killed in this city in 1968 in the lead-up to an Olympics where John Carlos and Tommie Smith made a Black Power salute. The Tlatelolco (“tlah-tay-LAWL-coh”) Massacre took place in, for 10 points, what capital of a country ruled by the PRI while a one-time member of NAFTA?
tossups.answer: Mexico City [or Ciudad de México; or CDMX]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Latin American> ~27437~ <Editor: Ganon Evans

bonuses.leadin: A Quranic prohibition on eating from dishes of gold or silver made this good popular in the Islamic world. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this luxury good produced in Jǐngdézhèn (“jeeng-duh-JEN”). This good was admired in the West for its ability to serve hot beverages, where it is often referred to just as “china.”

Blue-and-white Jǐngdézhèn porcelain relied on this element, which was mined in Kashan. Siddarth Kara’s book about the “red” form of this element details dangerous artisanal mining practices in the DRC.
This “porcelain sick” monarch traded 600 Saxon dragoons for 151 Empire Vases with William I of Prussia. Meissen (“MY-sen”) porcelain was developed under this monarch.
answers: Augustus the Strong [or Augustus II or Augustus the Saxon Hercules or Augustus Iron-Hand; prompt on Augustus]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22858~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: A character created by this author constantly uses the swearword “demmed” and escapes by giving Chauvelin (“SHOW-vil-lon”) pepper to sniff instead of snuff. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Hungarian-British baroness. This author created Sir Blakeney, who pretends to be an idiotic dandy to conceal his secret identity as the Scarlet Pimpernel.
Sir Blakeney has this first name. This was the first name of an author who wrote “ye are many, they are few” in his poem decrying the Peterloo Massacre, “The Masque of Anarchy.”
The Scarlet Pimpernel is set during this conflict. In A Tale of Two Cities, Sydney Carton is guillotined during this conflict.
answers: Baroness Orczy (“ahrt-see”) [or Emma Orczy or Emmuska Orczy; or Emma Magdalena Rozália Mária Jozefa Borbála Orczy de Orci]
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Long Fiction> ~22671~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: This person was the subject of a 2019 documentary subtitled “Yogi, Guru, Predator.” For 10 points each:
parts: Give the first or last name of this yoga guru whose namesake āsana-centric variant of hot yoga declined in popularity after he fled the US to escape sexual abuse charges.

Bikram yoga rejected the traditional Hatha emphasis on prāṇāyāma, in which the practitioner focuses on this physical action. Hatha tradition teaches ways to perform this action through the nose or mouth.
Bikram’s Beverly Hills yoga studio attracted this athlete, who wrote the book Mycroft and Sherlock and long struggled to get reporters to stop calling him “Lew Alcindor.”
answers: breathing [or respiration; accept word forms such as taking a breath]
bonuses.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~22611~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: A successful 2022 clinical trial that enrolled just five patients with this disease sparked efforts to treat it using CAR-T (“car T”) cells. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this autoimmune disease that presents with a butterfly-shaped facial rash. However, its name is derived from a different animal.
To treat autoimmune diseases, CARs are grafted onto these CD4 and CD25-positive T cells. These immuno·suppressive T cells prevent hyper·activation of helper T cells.

Before CAR-Tregs, lupus therapies dosed the mesenchymal (“mezz-en-KIE-mull”) type of these other cells. These pluripotent cells can be extracted from embryos and will differentiate into most other cell types.
answers: stem cells [or embryonic stem cells or ESCs; or mesenchymal stem cells or MSCs]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~23322~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. For her longest-running series, Ana Mendieta photographed this shape imprinted into mud, dirt, and other materials. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this shape which was often drawn with a hole through it by an artist who was inspired by hieroglyphics to draw stretched and curved examples of these shapes in works like Tuttomondo.

In a Silueta produced in Iowa, Mendieta wrapped herself in cloth to resemble one of these artifacts. In the 19th century, these artifacts were ground into a brown paint after being imported from Egyptian excavations.
This other artist asked models to cover themselves in paint and lay on a canvas for his Anthropométries series. This French artist became obsessed with a namesake “International” shade of blue.
answers: human body [accept obvious equivalents such as the human figure or the shape of a human; accept humans or people; accept referential terms such as the artist’s body or her body; accept a silhouette; accept Siluetas; prompt on outlines; prompt on stick figures] (Tuttomondo is by Keith Haring.)
mummies [accept mummified bodies; accept mummy brown; prompt on dead bodies or corpses or similar answers that don’t mention being mummified]

bonuses.leadin: Herodotus recorded how these peoples’ class of enarai (“en-ARE-ey”) were androgynous shamans affected by impotence as a result of excessive horse-riding. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this nomadic people who dominated the Pontic Steppe during Classical Greece. Under Queen Tomyris, their Massagetae (“mass-uh-GAY-tigh”) subgroup killed Cyrus the Great.

Androgynous priests known as Galli facilitated the worship of this Roman cult deity. Priests bathed in bull’s blood to honor this mother goddess, whose cult became popular during the Second Punic War.
Shortly before his exile to the Black Sea, this Roman poet described the androgynous Hermaphroditus in his Metamorphoses.
answers: Scythians [accept Scyths or Skythoi or Skolotoi; accept Saka or Sacae or Skuda; accept Saka tigraxaudā; reject “Sarmatians”]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - European - Classical> ~20920~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: PEP 484 adds “hints” for this property to Python that allow for its static assignment following a colon or arrow. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property that is assigned dynamically in Python. Python implements a lenient scheme for this property that is named for ducks.
These static code analysis tools can check for typing issues in source code that would be caught by strict compilers. These programs are named for a metaphor about cleaning clothes.

Hungarian notation includes the type in the names of functions and these things, which can be declared with the line of code, “int x semicolon.” In general, these things are contrasted with constants.
answers: type [accept duck typing or static typing or statically typed or dynamic typing or dynamically typed; accept word forms of type, like typed, in any acceptable answer]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Science - Computer Science> ~22160~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: This character ends her exile in France after a confrontation with her childhood friend Baasie, in which he criticized her for not knowing his real name. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who gets caught up in a 1976 uprising while working as a physiotherapist in Soweto.
Burger’s Daughter is by this 1991 Nobel Prize–winning South African author of July’s People.
In this Gordimer novel, the rich businessman Mehring begins to feel haunted after Jacobus finds the body of an unknown man on his farm, which the farm workers later give a proper burial.
bonuses.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23566~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: It’s not the NPS, but this agency maintains eight times more mileage of road than the Interstate Highway System. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this agency whose namesake highways are usually marked with brown signs with a white border. It is also responsible for managing twenty National Grasslands.
The Forest Service still operates a few lookout towers for spotting these events. Houses built in the Wildland Urban Interface are particularly vulnerable to these natural disasters.
The USFS administers Admiralty Island National Monument within the large Tongass National Forest in this state’s southeast, which includes cities like Ketchikan.
answers: U.S. Forest Service [or USFS; prompt on Department of Agriculture]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - United States> ~22475~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: The quarter-comma meantone (“mean-tone”) type of these systems creates a dissonant “wolf interval.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these tuning systems. The most popular one of these systems used today “tames the wolf” by dividing an octave into 12 equally spaced intervals.
This composer developed his namesake temperament for the harpsichord. He also wrote a Treatise on Harmony and the opera Les indes galantes (“lez AHND-uh guh-LONT”).

Temperaments are also crucial to this family of fretted, plucked string instruments that includes the mandolin. The Renaissance composer John Dowland primarily wrote for these instruments, which have a pear-shaped body and rounded back.
answers: temperaments [accept equal temperament; prompt on equally tempered or tempering by asking “what system does that correspond to?”; reject “temper”]
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~22640~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Richard Bulliet explores why this technology declined in use in the Middle East in a book titled for it and the camel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technology that was independently invented in Mesoamerica, but only used for toys. A well-preserved example of this technology was found in the Ljubljana (“l’yoob-l’YAH-nuh”) Marshes in 2002.
The wheel likely developed in the later stage of this archaeological period, whose name translates to “new stone.”

An early depiction of wheeled vehicles appears on one of these objects from Bronocice (“bro-not-SEET-seh”) dated to the 3rd millennium BCE. The ancient Greeks painted mythological scenes onto examples of these objects known as krater (“kray-ter”).
answers: wheel [or wheel and axle; accept basic wheeled vehicles such as wagons or carts; accept The Camel and The Wheel; accept Ljubljana Marshes Wheel]
pots [or vases; or vessels; or amphorae; or urns; or jars; accept clay pots]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Miscellaneous> ~22141~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: In the Kojiki, a maiden stabs herself in the groin with a shuttle after a horse with this trait startles her. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this trait of a dead, piebald horse that Susano’o (“sue-sah-NOH-oh”) drops through the roof of a weaving hall, causing his sister to flee into a cave. In Aztec lore, Xipe Totec (“SHEEP-uh TOH-tek”) inflicts this trait upon himself to give maize to humanity.
Susanoo startles this kami of the sun, his sister, when he drops the flayed horse.

Susano’o trolled his sister after they created eight deities by performing this action on a sword and necklace. An early type of sake (“SAH-kay”) was brewed by virgins performing this action with rice at Shinto shrines.
answers: flayed [accept word forms such as a horse that is flayed; accept skinned or without skin; prompt on being a carcass]
chewing [or mastication; accepting spitting; accept chewing and spitting; prompt on vague answers like putting something in their mouth; prompt on eating]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - World Mythology> ~22599~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: A character manages to win an election for a position of this name after giving a rousing speech that denounces the passivity of Gregory’s speech. For 10 points each:
parts: In a 1908 novel, Gabriel Syme is elected to what title position in an anarchist group, which he learns is actually full of undercover agents?
The prisoner Friday is rescued and saved from cannibals before being converted to Christianity by the title character of this novel by Daniel Defoe.
The novel Saturday, which follows one day in the life of the neurosurgeon Harry Perowne, is by this author who wrote about Briony Tallis in Atonement.
bonuses.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~22670~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Chemical potential only depends on the activity of ions that are denoted by this two-letter abbreviation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this parenthetical two-letter notation used in chemical reaction formulas to indicate ions that are hydrated.
In the simplest double displacement reaction, two aqueous ions react and undergo this process, forming a solid product that drops out of solution.

When hydrated ions are slowly frozen, the ice crystallizes around the salts to form these host–guest complexes. According to a once-popular, now mostly debunked theory, frozen methane that’s released from these complexes could lead to runaway climate change.
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22776~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Terri Lyne Carrington compiled 101 “new” songs of this type as part of her work at Berklee’s Jazz and Gender Justice Institute, for 10 points each.
parts: Name this loose group of songs considered part of a jazz musician’s repertoire. The Real Book codified many of these songs, examples of which include “Stardust” and “Body and Soul.”

This musician’s song “Blue Nile” is included in New Standards. This musician recorded Journey in Satchidananda (“sat-chee-DA-nan-da”) and later recorded spiritual music on albums like Kirtan: Turiya Sings.
New Standards also includes “Pisces” by Mary Lou Williams, who played this instrument alongside her contemporary Herbie Hancock.
bonuses.metadata: Victor Pavao, Fine Arts - Jazz> ~23277~ <Editor: Victor Pavao

bonuses.leadin: This type of change is Hicks-neutral if it improves capital and labor equally. For 10 points each:
parts: Name or describe this type of change. In the Solow growth model, economies converge to a steady state unless this type of change occurs, causing a permanent increase in productivity.
The Solow model assumes this property, in which adding additional factors of production past an optimal point will result in smaller marginal increases in output.

In the Solow model, the income levels of poorer countries converge towards those of richer countries if the rate of this process is high. In microeconomics, consumers either spend their income or do this with it.
answers: technological growth [or technical change; or technological progress or technological change; accept any answers indicating that technology improves; accept increase in total factor productivity or TFP; prompt on increase in A]
saving money [or save money; accept savings rate; accept investing or investment]
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Social Science - Economics> ~23190~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the New York merchant humorously named Preserved (“preh-zur-VEHD”) Fish, for 10 points each.
parts: Fish’s fortune arose from dominating the sale of this good, which was boiled out in trypots from a source material collected in flensing.
Fish claimed he would run around in his nightshirt if this party won. Leaders of this party’s Conscience faction helped create a new party that replaced it in the Third Party System.
Fish was an early trader on the New York Stock Exchange, which developed on this street emblematic of Manhattan’s financial district.
answers: whale oil [accept word forms such as oil from whales; accept train-oil; prompt on oil; prompt on blubber; prompt on whales]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - American - Pre-1865> ~22308~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the poetry magazine Yugen, for 10 points each.
parts: Starting in 1958, Yugen published work by authors from this literary movement, which included Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg.

Yugen’s first edition included a Ginsberg poem titled for “Hitch-hiking” on this island, which at various times was home to Ernest Hemingway and Elizabeth Bishop. The line “She sang beyond the genius of the sea” opens a poem titled for this island.
Yugen was edited by Hettie Cohen and this other poet, to whom she was married. After moving away from Beat poetry, this poet wrote the play Dutchman.
answers: Beat poets [or Beat poetry; or the Beat Generation; accept Beatniks]
Key West [accept “Hitch-hiking Key West”; accept “The Idea of Order at Key West”; reject the “Florida Keys”]
Amiri Baraka [or Imamu Amiri Baraka; or Everett Leroy Jones ; or LeRoi Jones]
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - American - Poetry> ~23284~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: The Smith chart is normalized with respect to the reference value of this quantity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity whose “matching” is visualized on Smith charts. This quantity equals electrical resistance plus reactance times the imaginary unit, j.
In the Smith chart, the paths between points of equal resistance have this shape. A connected portion of the circumference of a circle has this shape.

The distance from the center of the Smith chart equals the magnitude of this quantity. This quantity, which measures an interruption to transmission, equals the difference between load and reference impedances over their sum.
answers: electrical impedance [or source impedance or reference impedance or characteristic impedance]
reflection coefficient [prompt on uppercase gamma; prompt on answers describing amount of reflection]
bonuses.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, Science - Physics> ~23228~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Melek Taus repented his refusal to perform this action by using his tears to quench Hell for 7,000 years. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action. Yazidis are accused of devil-worship because the Peacock Angel’s refusal to perform this action out of loyalty to God resembles Iblis’s refusal to perform it out of pride.
Melek Taus refuses to bow before Adam, who is created from this substance. Genesis 3 (“chapter 3”) states “For you are [this substance], and to [this substance] you shall return.”
Due to Melek Taus’s devil-like actions, Islamic law does not regard the Yazidis as these people. This term refers to non-Muslims like Christians and Jews who were inspired by previous revelations.
answers: bowing before Adam [or prostrating before Adam; accept word forms; prompt on bowing or prostrating by asking “before whom?”]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Other Religion> ~22584~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: Diasporic populations are having increasing influence on their home countries. For 10 points each:
parts: In 2023, this non-German politician called for doubling the number of polling stations in Berlin so expats could vote for him. This president has sought the extradition of Fethullah Gülen from Pennsylvania.
Rajiv Kumar, this politician’s Election Commissioner, has promoted e-voting so that 1.34 million “non-resident Indians” can more easily vote. This man leads the BJP.
This country’s Heritage Party is led by a politician born in California. In 2023, over 100,000 people fled the city of Stepanakert, largely taking refuge in this one-time Russian ally.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~22894~ <Editor: Michael Bentley
